option.name: updatedContent
updatedContent
option.value:
# L3 Engine - Log Extraction Tool ## Project Retrospective Brief
### Project Vision & Goals
**What We Set Out to Build:** The L3 Engine Log Extraction Tool was conceived to address a critical operational challenge faced by our airline operations team. When flight incidents occur, our support engineers need to quickly gather and analyze relevant log files from multiple systems to perform root cause analysis and resolve issues.
**The Problem We Aimed to Solve:** - **Manual Log Collection**: Engineers were spending hours manually collecting log files from various systems across different servers - **Time-Critical Analysis**: Flight incidents require rapid response, but log collection was becoming a bottleneck - **Scattered Data Sources**: Log files were distributed across multiple systems (DAS, MessageTypeB, MessageAPI, MessageForwarder) - **Inconsistent Process**: Different engineers had different approaches to log collection, leading to missed files or incomplete data sets
### Technical Architecture Decision
**Core Design Philosophy:** We designed the tool around a **pipeline-driven artifact collection** model, leveraging Azure DevOps pipelines to orchestrate log gathering from remote systems, then automatically downloading and organizing the results.
**Key Components:** 1. **Azure Pipeline Integration**: Trigger remote log collection processes via Azure DevOps API 2. **Artifact Management**: Download and extract build artifacts containing collected logs 3. **JavaFX Desktop Application**: Provide an intuitive interface for operations teams 4. **Message Extraction Engine**: Parse and analyze collected logs for specific flight data
### Expected Benefits
**Operational Efficiency:** - Reduce log collection time from hours to minutes - Standardize the log collection process across all engineers - Enable faster incident response and resolution
**Data Completeness:** - Ensure all relevant log sources are consistently collected - Reduce risk of missing critical log files during incident analysis - Provide comprehensive artifact organization and preview capabilities
**Team Productivity:** - Free up engineering time from manual log gathering tasks - Enable focus on actual analysis and problem-solving - Provide self-service capabilities for operations teams
### Implementation Approach
**Phase 1: Core Infrastructure** - Azure DevOps pipeline integration for triggering remote log collection - Build artifact download and extraction capabilities - Basic desktop application framework with JavaFX
**Phase 2: Enhanced Features** - Real-time pipeline status monitoring - File preview and organization capabilities - Configuration management for different environments
**Phase 3: Analysis Integration** - Message parsing and extraction from collected logs - Root cause analysis reporting features - Integration with existing operational workflows
### Success Metrics
**Performance Targets:** - Reduce log collection time by 80% (from 2-4 hours to 15-30 minutes) - Achieve 99%+ collection reliability across all target log sources - Support parallel processing of multiple flight incidents
**Quality Indicators:** - Zero missed log files during collection process - Standardized file organization and naming conventions - Comprehensive audit trail of collection activities
### Risk Mitigation Strategies
**Technical Risks:** - **Azure DevOps Dependency**: Implemented robust error handling and retry mechanisms - **Network Connectivity**: Added offline preview capabilities and local caching - **Authentication Issues**: Comprehensive token validation and detailed error messaging
**Operational Risks:** - **User Training**: Designed intuitive interface requiring minimal training - **Process Changes**: Maintained backward compatibility with existing workflows - **System Integration**: Flexible configuration system for different environments
---
*This retrospective represents the project vision and planning that guided the development of the L3 Engine Log Extraction Tool. The tool successfully addresses critical operational needs by automating and standardizing the log collection process for flight incident analysis.*

option.name: updatedContent
option.value:
--- ## Appendix B: Error Codes Reference L3 Engine uses standardized error codes to help you quickly identify and resolve issues. Each error includes a specific code, description, and resolution steps. ### B.1 Log Extraction Engine Errors (LE001-LE005) | Error Code | Description | What It Means | How to Fix | |------------|-------------|---------------|------------| | **LE001** | Azure configuration missing | Azure DevOps connection is not configured | Click the ⚙ Configure Azure button and enter your organization URL, project name, and Personal Access Token | | **LE002** | Invalid credentials | Your Personal Access Token is incorrect or expired | 1. Check your token is copied correctly
2. Generate a new token at Azure DevOps
3. Ensure token has Build and Release permissions | | **LE003** | Pipeline trigger failed | The extraction pipeline failed to start or execute | 1. Verify the flight operated on the specified date
2. Check Azure DevOps is accessible
3. Wait a few minutes and try again | | **LE004** | Network connectivity error | Cannot connect to Azure DevOps | 1. Check your internet connection
2. Verify Azure DevOps URL is correct
3. Contact IT if firewall may be blocking access | | **LE005** | Insufficient permissions | Your account lacks necessary Azure DevOps permissions | Contact your Azure DevOps administrator to grant Build and Release permissions | ### B.2 Log Parser Engine Errors (LP001-LP005) | Error Code | Description | What It Means | How to Fix | |------------|-------------|---------------|------------| | **LP001** | Invalid directory path | The selected log directory is invalid or inaccessible | 1. Ensure the directory exists
2. Check you have read permissions
3. Select a different directory | | **LP002** | No EDIFACT messages found | No passenger data found in the log files | 1. Verify logs contain passenger data
2. Check flight number and date accuracy
3. Try different data type (API ↔ PNR) | | **LP003** | Message parsing failed | Error processing passenger message format | 1. Verify flight number format (minimum 3 characters)
2. Ensure departure date is selected
3. Contact development team if issue persists | | **LP004** | Multi-node consolidation error | Failed to combine logs from multiple nodes | 1. Check n1/, n2/, n3/ subdirectories exist
2. Disable multi-node mode if not needed
3. Ensure subdirectories contain log files | | **LP005** | File format not supported | The log file format cannot be processed | 1. Verify you're using standard application log files
2. Check files aren't corrupted
3. Contact support for format assistance | ### B.3 RCA Engine Errors (RCA001-RCA005) | Error Code | Description | What It Means | How to Fix | |------------|-------------|---------------|------------| | **RCA001** | No passenger files found | No data files available for analysis | 1. Select a folder containing input/ and output/ subdirectories
2. Process logs through Log Parser Engine first
3. Verify folder contains passenger data files | | **RCA002** | File parsing error | Error reading or processing passenger data files | 1. Ensure files weren't manually modified
2. Verify file format is correct
3. Try processing smaller data sets | | **RCA003** | Data validation failed | Passenger records contain invalid or missing information | 1. Check source data quality
2. Review warnings list for specific issues
3. Fix data at source if possible | | **RCA004** | Excel export failed | Cannot generate or save the analysis report | 1. Check available disk space
2. Ensure output directory is writable
3. Close Excel if it's open and try again | | **RCA005** | Memory allocation error | Insufficient memory to process the dataset | 1. Close other applications
2. Process smaller data sets
3. Consider increasing system memory | ### B.4 Flight Number Validation Rules **Valid Flight Number Formats:** - Minimum 3 characters, maximum 8 characters - Can contain letters, numbers, and the + symbol - Examples: `WF123`, `AI101`, `6E2024`, `SG+8475` **Important Notes:** - **Log Extractor**: Accepts + symbol between carrier code and flight number (e.g., `SG+8475`) - **Log Parser/RCA Engine**: Flight numbers should follow standard airline format - Not case-sensitive (`wf123` works same as `WF123`) ### B.5 Troubleshooting Quick Reference **Most Common Issues:** 1. **"Azure configuration missing" (LE001)** - **Solution**: Click ⚙ Configure Azure → Enter organization, project, token → Save 2. **"No EDIFACT messages found" (LP002)** - **Solution**: Try switching data type (API ↔ PNR) → Verify flight number/date 3. **"No passenger files found" (RCA001)** - **Solution**: Use Log Parser Engine first → Select correct folder structure 4. **"Pipeline trigger failed" (LE003)** - **Solution**: Check flight date accuracy → Verify Azure connection → Retry 5. **"Multi-node consolidation error" (LP004)** - **Solution**: Turn OFF multi-node mode → Or ensure n1/, n2/, n3/ folders exist ### B.6 Getting Additional Help If you encounter errors not covered in this guide: 1. **Check the application log area** - Look for detailed error messages 2. **Try the suggested resolution steps** - Follow the specific guidance for your error code 3. **Contact your team lead** - For Azure DevOps access or configuration issues 4. **Contact development team** - For persistent technical issues or unknown error codes **When reporting issues, include:** - The exact error code (e.g., LE003, LP002) - What you were trying to do when the error occurred - Flight number and date you were investigating - Any additional error messages from the application log area --- **Document Version:** 3.2.0.0 **Last Updated:** November 25, 2024 **Contact:** L3 Engine Development Team

option.name: updatedContent
option.value:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <project xmlns="http://maven.apache.org/POM/4.0.0" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://maven.apache.org/POM/4.0.0 https://maven.apache.org/xsd/maven-4.0.0.xsd"> <modelVersion>4.0.0</modelVersion>
<groupId>com.l3</groupId> <artifactId>engine</artifactId> <version>1.0-SNAPSHOT</version> <name>L3 Engine</name>
<properties> <project.build.sourceEncoding>UTF-8</project.build.sourceEncoding> <junit.version>5.10.2</junit.version> <maven.compiler.source>21</maven.compiler.source> <maven.compiler.target>21</maven.compiler.target> <javafx.version>21</javafx.version> </properties>
<dependencies> <dependency> <groupId>org.openjfx</groupId> <artifactId>javafx-controls</artifactId> <version>21</version> </dependency> <dependency> <groupId>org.openjfx</groupId> <artifactId>javafx-fxml</artifactId> <version>21</version> </dependency>
<!-- Apache POI for Excel generation --> <dependency> <groupId>org.apache.poi</groupId> <artifactId>poi</artifactId> <version>5.2.5</version> </dependency> <dependency> <groupId>org.apache.poi</groupId> <artifactId>poi-ooxml</artifactId> <version>5.2.5</version> </dependency>
<!-- Log4j2 core implementation to fix logging warning --> <dependency> <groupId>org.apache.logging.log4j</groupId> <artifactId>log4j-core</artifactId> <version>2.21.1</version> </dependency>
<dependency> <groupId>org.junit.jupiter</groupId> <artifactId>junit-jupiter-api</artifactId> <version>${junit.version}</version> <scope>test</scope> </dependency> <dependency> <groupId>org.junit.jupiter</groupId> <artifactId>junit-jupiter-engine</artifactId> <version>${junit.version}</version> <scope>test</scope> </dependency> <dependency> <groupId>org.testng</groupId> <artifactId>testng</artifactId> <version>7.5</version> <scope>compile</scope> </dependency> </dependencies>
<build> <plugins> <plugin> <groupId>org.apache.maven.plugins</groupId> <artifactId>maven-compiler-plugin</artifactId> <version>3.13.0</version> <configuration> <source>21</source> <target>21</target> </configuration> </plugin>
<!-- Maven Shade Plugin for creating executable JAR --> <plugin> <groupId>org.apache.maven.plugins</groupId> <artifactId>maven-shade-plugin</artifactId> <version>3.5.1</version> <executions> <execution> <phase>package</phase> <goals> <goal>shade</goal> </goals> <configuration> <transformers> <transformer implementation="org.apache.maven.plugins.shade.resource.ManifestResourceTransformer"> <mainClass>com.l3.apipnrengine.controller.MainApp</mainClass> </transformer> </transformers> <filters> <filter> <artifact>*:*</artifact> <excludes> <exclude>META-INF/*.SF</exclude> <exclude>META-INF/*.DSA</exclude> <exclude>META-INF/*.RSA</exclude> </excludes> </filter> </filters> </configuration> </execution> </executions> </plugin>
<plugin> <groupId>org.openjfx</groupId> <artifactId>javafx-maven-plugin</artifactId> <version>0.0.8</version> <executions> <execution> <!-- Default configuration for running with: mvn clean javafx:run --> <id>default-cli</id> <configuration> <mainClass>com.l3.apipnrengine.controller.MainApp</mainClass> <launcher>app</launcher> <jlinkZipName>app</jlinkZipName> <jlinkImageName>app</jlinkImageName> <noManPages>true</noManPages> <stripDebug>true</stripDebug> <noHeaderFiles>true</noHeaderFiles> </configuration> </execution> </executions> </plugin> </plugins> </build> </project>
